RBG's health. She has had 3 prior cancers and broken ribs, which is indicative of probable osteoporosis. Her health is not very good and the fact
that her doctors gave her radiation instead of surgery for treating pancreatic cancer indicates her health is poor. Pancreatic cancer is among the
most lethal of cancers and her cancer has flared up for the 2nd time. Luck is finite even for the most fortunate, Health In 1999, Ginsburg was diagnosed with colon cancer; she underwent surgery that was followed by chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
On February 5, 2009, she again underwent surgery, this time for pancreatic cancer. Ginsburg had a tumor that was discovered at an early stage. She was released from a New York City hospital on February 13 and returned to the bench when the Supreme Court went back into session on February 23, 2009. On September 24, 2009, Ginsburg was hospitalized in Washington, DC, for lightheadedness following an outpatient treatment for iron deficiency and was released the following day. On November 26, 2014, she had a stent placed in her right coronary artery after experiencing discomfort while exercising in the Supreme Court gym with her personal trainer. On November 8, 2018, she was hospitalized after fracturing three ribs in a fall in her office at the Supreme Court. A day later, it was reported that Ginsburg had returned to official judicial work after a day of observation.  A CT scan of her ribs following her November 8 fall showed cancerous nodules in her lungs. On December 21, Ginsburg underwent a left-lung lobectomy at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center to remove the nodules. On January 7, 2019, for the first time since joining the Court more than 25 years earlier, Ginsburg missed oral argument while she recuperated.[128] 
On August 24, 2019, it was revealed that Ginsburg had recently completed three weeks of focused radiation treatment to ablate a tumor found in her pancreas over the summer.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_Bader_Ginsburg#Health Elderly trauma patients with rib fractures are at greater risk of death and pneumonia. After adjusting for severity (i.e., ISS and Revised Trauma Score), comorbidity, and multiple rib fractures, patients aged > or = 65 had five times the odds of dying when compared with those < 65 years old.

RESULTS: Overall median survival was 6.2 months. Patients who underwent surgical therapy had the best median survival rate of 26.5 months, followed by patients receiving chemotherapy (6.6 months), chemoradiotherapy (5.7 months) and best supportive care (3.4 months). Further analysis showed that the median survival of chemotherapy and chemoradiotherapy groups was 8.1 and 11.3 months for stage III, 6.2 and 3.9 months for stage IV respectively. Independent negative prognostic factor for survival were Karnofsky performance status < or = 80 and presence of distant metastases.

Changing my forecast from 4% to 0%, based on the following rationale.... Thinking about 3 zones for updating my forecast for this question: 1) What is obvious? All things in consideration, health is good, RBG will not retire in the next 83 days, etc.  She's a fighter with lots of support. She's not going anywhere for any forecastible reason. In other words, very strong signal that RBG will not cease to be an AJ by 1/1/20. 2) What is forecastible? Mortality rates based on age, gender, supreme court justices, cancer history, etc. Also, rates of retirement, removal from the supreme court, etc. All of these are throwing strong signal that RBG will not cease to be an AJ by 1/1/20. 3) What is unforeseeable and unforecastable? Examples are dies in car crash, fall down stairs and dies from injuries, chokes on food and dies. Commits a Vontae Davis, etc. Nobody can forecast whether such an event will occur in the next 83 days. Possible, but not forecastable, within the boundaries of the question. Do I include a sliver of % yes to accommodate possibility of an event occuring that I cannot foresee? The only option is 1%, since GJP doesn't allow portions or a percent. Seems similar to someone asking me before I get on a plane, "How sure are you that you will safely land at your destination?" My answer would be 100%, knowing full well that not 100% of planes that take off safely land. A few crash, but a de minimis risk is rounded to zero. I think the amount of unforecastable risk in this case is de minimis and can be safely ignored here.

"Before her latest cancer was diagnosed, Ginsburg said she hoped to stay on the bench for at least five more years, noting that Associate Justice John Paul Stevens served until age 90. Stevens died in July at 99. The latest health scare is particularly worrisome to many because it's her second bout with pancreatic cancer. The average five-year survival rate is 9%, lowest of all cancers. But Ginsburg has lived 10 years since her first bout. The Pancreatic Cancer Action Network's website lists the names of public figures whose lives have been impacted by pancreatic cancer. The list includes 16 survivors such as opera singer Marilyn Horne, whose vow to live following her 2005 diagnosis Ginsburg admires. But it also names more than 250 public figures who succumbed to the disease. Julie Fleshman, the network's president and CEO, says the three weeks of radiation Ginsburg received at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York is the go-to treatment for small, localized tumors. A more serious form of the cancer would have called for surgery or further treatment, she says.  The justice's first major health scare was colon cancer in 1999. Chemotherapy and radiation left her depleted, so her late husband Martin convinced her to get a personal trainer. She has worked out twice a week ever since." https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/09/20/ruth-bader-ginsburg-supreme-courts-liberal-leader-unbowed-cancer/2367040001/

"There are two main types of pancreatic cancer: Adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine carcinoma. According to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network, about 90% of pancreatic cancers fall into the first category, which has a lower survival rate. According to the American Cancer Society, the five-year survival rate for localized adenocarcinoma is about 34%. In comparison, the five-year survival rate for localized neuroendocrine carcinoma is about 94%.  There is reason to believe that Ginsburg has the less common, more survivable form of cancer. That is because Ginsburg was treated for pancreatic cancer 10 years ago, and is still alive. That makes it likely that Ginsburg had neuroendocrine carcinoma, and that it came back, Mount Sinai’s Flores said. “My sense, because she is alive a decade later, leads me to believe it was more likely a neuroendocrine carcinoma,” Flores said.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg assumed office in 1993, and it is well understood that Supreme Court Justices serve for life, for an average of 35 years. It is extremely unlikely that she will quit or be dismissed (given her extensive accomplishments in the field and her prominence in advocating for women's rights), however, given her age and her health (she is currently 86 years old and has been in and out of the hospital for cancer treatment since 1999. In August 24 2019, it was revealed that she is underwent radiation treatment for pancreatic tumors over the summer), it may be likely that she will be forced to retire due to her health.  Radiation treatment is hard on the body, however it also seems that she is passionate about what she does. For this reason, I believe there may be a possibility that she will cease to be an Associate Justice due to health reasons.

Oh, no.  Ginsburg defeated her earlier pout of pancreatic cancer in 2009.  While the 5-year survival rate for pancreatic cancer is only 17% (not much different from the 10-year survival rate), but she beat it. But now it comes back.   According to NPR, she has localized (not metastatic, earliest stage) pancreatic cancer [1].  The 1-year survival rate for localized pancreatic cancer is 40.5% [2], using data for National Institute of Cancer's SEER (Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results) Program which include all races, all ages and both sexes.   But better treatment can double the survival rates, especially the early years, even for metastatic stages [3].  I am sure she has better treatment than the average person.  Using this statistics, her 1-year survival rate is 81%.  Scale this to 5 months (August to December) gives 90% survival rate.  This gives a 10% chance for her not being on the Supreme Court by end of December. Note that these calculations are based on localized pancreatic cancer as reported by NPR [1].  At later stages, the survival rates are much lower - it is a nasty cancer to have. Sure - there is, for example, this in the  news: "The new tumor on her pancreas was detected after a routine blood test in early July". Well, there are NO routine tests for pancreatic tumors. In fact, there is only one test, very much targeted specifically to pancreatic cancers, that even has a chance to detect one. In the last month,  someone close and dear to me was diagnosed with small cell lung cancer.  18 yrs ago this same person had squamous cell lung cancer.  So, now I think I know a little bit about both of the main types of lung cancer. Squamous cell lung cancer is the more common type of lung cancer, these days.  It is a skin cancer that forms a well-defined tumor.  It is usually curable through surgery, and often there is no need for follow-up radiation or chemo.  Recovery time post-op for non-strenuous activity is measured in days to weeks.  After successful surgery,  the patient is declared cancer-free.  "Cure" is declared only after 5 yrs if there has been no recurrence.   Small cell lung cancer causes a less well-defined tumor.  It is usually treated by  chemotherapy, and about 30 radiation treatments which take only a few minutes each day.  Chemo is usually administered on a 21 or 28 day cycle,  with the first day of the cycle involving a lengthy infusion (about 6 hrs), followed by treatments of 1-2 hrs on days 2 & 3, and then another 48 hrs during which the patient is considered toxic  (think of them as being Roundup or bleach in body shape) and will have restricted freedom.   There may be 5, or more, cycles of chemo.   These treatments can cause a dramatic reduction in immunity (low WBC counts) which can take a week or more to reverse, during which time the patient has to be in isolation.   As far as I know, once treatment has begun, it will be about half a year before it may result in the patient being declared "cancer-free". The median survival rate for small cell lung cancer is about 15 months.   Prior to embarking on treatment of either type of lung cancer doctors usually do a PET scan to look for metastases to other organs and an MRI to look for a tumor in the brain (which is where lung cancer normally metastasizes to).  They would not declare a patient "cancer-free" after treatment for lung cancer if they saw cancer elsewhere in those scans; in fact, they might not have embarked on treatment at all if they had found anything elsewhere. These descriptions of treatment are not precisely duplicated in every situation for every patient, but the point is that with squamous cell lung cancer the treatment is a one-time procedure with a recovery period of under a month, but with small cell lung cancer the treatment is much more debilitating and takes months--like half a year--and frequent periods of isolation and treatment. Nobody is saying which type of lung cancer RBG had, but look at how soon she was back on the bench and how available she has been to the press and public.  I have read that the doctors have declared her "cancer-free".  Thus,  I am 99% sure she had a squamous cell lung cancer.   Therefore, I think her odds of dying of lung cancer in the next 6 months are very low:  1%.  Therefore, her survival odds are about "normal" for a woman of her age, about 7% per year.  Adjusted for the fact that we're 6 months into the year, makes the base rate about 3%.  However, everything I read says that RBG is very health-conscious and I assume she gets excellent medical care, so I'll reduce her odds by 2/3rds to 1%. Furthermore,  I think her odds of resigning voluntarily are next to nil. What am I missing? EDIT:  @Emil, @dlaiocean, @Resonancia, @1291, @rjfmgy, @GL2814, @nonplus, @nigster

Social Security Administration actuarial tables for 2016: https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html RBG turned 86 in March 2019, her death probability is 0.082465. The death probability for 87 year old is one percent higher at 0.092370. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have a chart of top ten causes of death for people ages 65+: https://www.cdc.gov/injury/wisqars/pdf/10lcid_all_deaths_by_age_group_2010-a.pdf Heart disease is the leading cause, but less likely since she appears to have a personal trainer. Second most likely cause is malignant neoplasms, aka tumor, aka cancer, which she's had numerous encounters with. Respiratory and cerebro-vascular disease are, like heart disease, perhaps less likely since she's not shown these illnesses. The chart doesn't have an "other" row but since the 10th most likely cause of death is 1/20th the most likely cause, perhaps we can ignore these. I'd like to de-weight the nine causes of death other than cancer to 70%, and leave cancer at 100% weight—here I'm reducing the odds that she dies of one of these nine non-cancer illnesses by 30% in order to personalize the marginal probability (which by definition is averaged over all conditionals) more to RBG. The resulting weight (80%) can then be used to scale the death probability from SSA. Using the average between the 86 and 87 year old death probabilities of 8.2 and 9.2 percent gives us 8.7%. Scaling 8.7% by the overall weight from the CDC analysis of causes of death gives 6.99% probability of dying this year. Right now there are seven months left in the year. Assuming all days are equally likely to result in death, we can scale 7% probability of dying this year with 7/12, giving 4.08%. Apparently she's very unlikely to quit just because of her health, since that'd give the current president another appointment. The question leaves open the possibility that she gets promoted to chief justice but Justice Roberts would have to be evicted and nobody else but her appointed, giving that negligible probability. Going with 4%, the probability that she'll die in the next seven months, after de-weighting nine of the ten leading causes of death among those 65+ in age by 70% while leaving one (cancer) at 100% weight.

We can predict the total probability that Ruth Bader Ginsburg will cease to be an Associate Justice of the US Supreme Court before 1 January 2020 by adding up the probabilities that she will either die, retire voluntarily, or retire due to health concerns (e.g cancer, stroke, dementia, nonfatal heart attack, nonfatal fall, etc.).  Will she die? - Ruth Bader Ginsburg is 86 years old. According to the US Government's Social Security actuarial life tables (https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html), the Death Probability (that is, the chances that an individual will die within the next year) is 0.082465, or roughly 8.2%, for an 86 year old female in the US. We can expect that due to her lifelong elevated socioeconomic status, healthy lifestyle, and access to the highest level of healthcare, the percent probability of her death in 2019 would actually be lower than this.  However, Ginsburg's medical history suggests she is at greater risk of dying of cancer. After the cancerous lesions were removed from her lungs in December 2018, her doctors have stated that there is an 80% chance of being cancer-free five years out (in other words, a 20% chance that she will have another recurrence of lung cancer in that time - for this analysis let's assume a flat rate of 4% per year). Also, people who have had cancer once are more likely to get a second unrelated cancer, as Ginsburg herself has (she had pancreatic cancer previously). In sum, we can assess there is a higher chance that Ginsburg will be diagnosed with cancer in 2019 than her cohort. Total chances of dying: 8.2% + 4% = 12.2% Will she retire? - Given Ginsburg's status as one of the 4 liberal justices on the Court, the fact that the last two Supreme Court Justices to be appointed were nominated by a Republican President, and that that President will remain President until at least January 20, 2021, we can assess the likelihood that she will retire while Donald Trump is still be responsible for nominating her replacement as 0%. This may change if Trump wins a second term, but that wouldn't happen until November 2020. Will she retire due to debilitating illness? As previously stated, she has had numerous health scares from cancers and falls and also has had multiple surgeries (https://www.vox.com/2018/11/12/18080366/ruth-bader-ginsburg-movie-health). While these have yet to adversely impact her ability to serve on the Supreme Court, the chances that they will do so only increases with time. However, it is assumed from past experience that cancer and falls will either be fatal or recoverable in a way as to not impact her ability to continue on on the Court, at least until the end of the year. Two age-related illnesses that may impact her ability to serve as a Justice are stroke and dementia. Due to her advanced age, she is at risk of stroke (assumed to be roughly 15% - https://jnnp.bmj.com/content/74/3/317). Additionally, her chances of developing dementia are estimated to be 1 in 6, or about 17% (https://www.alzheimers.org.uk/sites/default/files/pdf/factsheet_risk_factors_for_dementia.pdf), however it is unlikely that dementia would have a fast enough onset to cause her to retire in just the remainder of this year.  Adding up the probabilities of debilitating illness: 15% (stroke) + 5% (dementia, reduced to account for lower likelihood of fast onset) = 20% In total: Est. probability of death (12.2%) + certain probability of voluntary retirement (0%) + Est. probability of debilitating illness (20%) = 32.2% that Ruth Bader Ginsburg ceases to be a Supreme Court Justice by 1 January 2020.

The two reasons Ruth Bader Ginsburg would cease to be an Associate Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court is either retirement/resignation or death. Given the current political climate and her strong distaste for President Trump, it seems very unlikely that she would retire willingly before the 1 of January 2020. This would voluntarily give another spot on the Supreme Court that Trump would fill. Using the ODNI chart, the probability  of her retirement would be "highly improbable" with a percentage between 5-20%. I predict this percentage is on the higher side at 15% due to her declining health, where there is probability of forced retirement by doctors. 
On the other hand, the other reason she would cease to be on the Supreme Court is her death. Generally speaking, the life expectancy for women in the United States is 78 years old; however, the expectancy for affluent, white women rises to 84.3. Currently, RBG is 86, making her above the average life expectancy. In December of 2018, two cancerous nodes were found on RBGs left lung. Net survival of lung cancer for women between 80-99 years old is 7%; however, the average time the cancer lasts after diagnosis is 5 years. If she was diagnosed in December of 2018, this would put the average date of death at December of 2023 which is way beyond January 2020. RBG is likely to have the highest quality of care in the country given her position and income level, perhaps giving her more years and making death less likely. On the contrary, her age makes other causes of death that are unexpected more likely. From all of these statistics, I would predict that RBG dying before 1 of January 2020 is unlikely with an average of 25%.  When we average the 15% probability of retirement and 25% probability of death, this leaves a 20% probability of Ruth Bader Ginsburg ceasing to be an Associate Justice of the US Supreme Court before January 1, 2020.  Sources: 
-https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/31/politics/ruth-bader-ginsburg-democrats/index.html
-https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R44846.pdf
-https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/health-professional/cancer-statistics/statistics-by-cancer-type/lung-cancer/survival#heading-One

It's my first forecast, so be gentle, people. RBG could not be an associate justice on Jan. 1, 2020 because she: 1. dies (of natural causes or by other means); 2. retires/leaves office (either voluntarily; due to physical/mental incapacity; impeached); 3. becomes the Chief Justice.  Scenario 1: What's the likelihood of RBG dying before Jan. 1, 2020? RBG is current 86 years old. The life expectancy of a woman at her age is 6.43 years. Therefore, I can expect her to live to 92.43 years old, which would mean that she'd be alive on Jan 1, 2020. The probability of her death is 0.084033 (according to the Social Security actuarial table), but we have some other factors to consider. Her mother died of cancer at the age of 48 (1902-1950); her father died at 71 (1896-1968)--his cause of death is unclear. Some studies indicate that children of people who had cancer have a higher likelihood of also having cancer (https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/causes-of-cancer/inherited-cancer-genes-and-increased-cancer-risk/family-history-and-inherited-cancer-genes). However, since I don't know the type of cancer her mother died from, it's difficult to account for it. We also know that she had a tumor removed successfully in 2018 (with a 86% recovery rate), so we can also assume that she has access to good health care and is taking some proactive measures in regards to her health. Her race and educational status also play a role. Research also indicates that white women with higher educational attainment have a lower risk of mortality (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4435622/)--mortality was 38% higher in women 65-84 with 9-11 years of school compared with those who had 17 or more years. In consideration of these elements, it seems not very likely that she'll die by natural causes before Jan. 1, 2020. Based on the Social Security table, the probability is 0.084033 (8.4033%), leaving a 91.6% chance that she'll still be alive.  Then there's the question of death by other means. There has only been one known attempt to assassinate a Justice, and it was unsuccessful. So let's set that chance at very, very low.  Scenario 2: what's the likelihood of her retiring/being removed from office before Jan. 1, 2020?  RBG has served on the Supreme Court since 1993, a 26 year term. Justices appointed between 1966 and the present have served an average of 24 years (not counting current Justices--https://www.vox.com/2016/2/17/11032182/pope-president-and-justice-ages). The longest-serving Justice was 36 years and 7 months (there have been 113 Justices, so 1/113th have served 36 years). Of the living Justices who retired: Justice Stevens (35 years); O'Connor (25 years); Kennedy (30 years); Souter (19 years)--average of 27.75 years. So she's slightly above the average term but slightly below the number of years of retired living Associate Justices. If she will stay in her position for the average of retired living Justices, that would put her in office past Jan. 1, 2020.  On the question of being impeached: only one Justice has ever been impeached by the House (Justice Chase). The Democrats will control the House until at least Jan. 1, 2020, so there's very small chance they would impeach her. Even Chase, who was awful, wasn't removed after trial in the Senate. So let's set that chance very, very low, too.  Maybe we should add in a very low chance of some radically unexpected possibility: a military coup that eliminates the Supreme Court; a national emergency where the President dissolves the Court; a Constitutional amendment goes through some kind of hyper-political drive and abolishes the Court. Who knows. Wacky times.  Scenario 3: What's the likelihood of RBG being made Chief Justice?  5 of the 17 Chief Justices served as Associate Justices before becoming Chief, so .294117 probability. However, Chief Justice Roberts would have to either die, retire, or be removed from office for the spot to open up. He has only been on the Court for 14 years, and he is relatively young (64). So either of those events happening seems very unlikely. He has 18.53 expected remaining years and a 0.014979 probability of dying. He's well below the average term for a modern Justice to retire, and since the Senate is controlled by Republicans, it seems unlikely that he'd be impeached by the House and convicted by the Senate. So let's throw in another very low chance of this happening.  Therefore, the most likely event would be RBG's retirement, either voluntarily or due to incapacity. Based on the above figures, let's call it a 19.8% chance of one of the events happening. But it has been a really, really long time since I've taken a math class. I probably have oversimplified the last step. The last scenario should be given less weight because of how unlikely it seems. So I'll bring the number down to 17% to try and account for that .  As for some of the other estimates that involved her desire to stay on the Court as long as possible: I don't think we can reliably factor in her determination to stay in office until the next Presidential term since she would not have any choice at all about her own retirement (mental/physical incapacity) or death (natural or otherwise). Our physiologies rarely care about our desires.

I looked at the actuarial life tables on ssa.gov and it says that an 85 year old has a 7.5 percent chance of dying within the next year. Because RBG is sick, I doubled my estimate to 15%. Included in that 7.5% number, is some chance that she will die from cancer. Maybe 50% of other 85 year olds also have cancer or comparably risky health problems. She had colon cancer in 1999 (age 66), pancreatic cancer in 2009 (age 76), a heart stent in 2014 (age 81), and lung cancer in 2018 (age 85).  Percent surviving 5 years for colon cancer: 65% / pancreatic: 9% / lung: 19%. It's been 19 years since her 1st cancer. If you have a 20 percent chance of dying within 5 years from lung cancer, that's a 4% chance each year. She has had lots of cancer, and it's been 19 years, so each extra year of life probably carries more than a 4% chance of death. That is why I just doubled 7.5% to 15%.

I'm imagining Justice Ginsburg will remain on the bench unless she dies, gets sick with a debilitating illness, retires or is fired or forced to resign for some unknown reason. For simplicity I am treating these as independent possibilities, with annual probabilities small enough that they can be equated to annual frequencies, and as such I will combine the four frequency estimates to obtain the current expected annual frequency of hypothetical release from the bench. Then, if the combined annual frequency is low enough, I can equate it to the annual probability.
Her baseline probability of death over the next year, from online actuarial tables, is 8.40% (I have taken the value for a 86 year old woman).
Her chance of contracting a debilitating illness are a guess at this point. I'm not sure what the probability of a 86 year old white woman being hospitalized, bedridden or mentally incapacitated over the following year. I think some possibilities (i.e. Alzheimer's) are not credible, new (previously undiagnosed) diseases are unlikely; to me the most likely negative scenario is a bad fall and broken hip or equivalent. I think the chances are maybe 2 to 5 % over the next year.
She has said she won't retire, but surely something could happen to change her mind. Apart from health issues, which I've already accounted for, I can't see her stepping out of her role, so I give this no more than 1% chance in the next year.
Only one supreme court justice has even been impeached, according to the internet (Samuel Chase, 1804), and he was acquitted by the senate. I think the idea of Justice Ginsberg being forced off the court is ridiculously implausible, and assign it 0%. I would give this a negative probability if I could. :-)
If I combine my possibilities, I get about 12%, which is my current (first) guess.

Like the malignant lung nodules, both previous cancers were discovered by chance and had not spread elsewhere in the body.  “It’s not clear whether [the lung cancer] is a primary cancer or one that has spread from another place. Colon cancer doesn’t generally spread to the lungs. Pancreatic cancer can spread virtually anywhere,” says Horovitz. “If these nodules were a primary lung cancer limited to that lobe, we can hope that this [surgery] was a cure.”
https://www.webmd.com/lung-cancer/news/20181221/ruth-bader-ginsburg-lung-cancer-surgery some generally positive factors that might also improve RBG's chances of at least a 1  year recovery here:
Age: Younger people tend to live longer than older people with lung cancer.
Sex: The life expectancy for a woman with lung cancer is higher at each stage of the disease.
General health: Being healthy overall at the time of diagnosis is associated with a longer life expectancy, and a greater ability to withstand treatments that may extend survival.
Response to treatment: Side effects of treatment vary among different people, and may limit your ability to tolerate treatment.
Other health conditions you may have: Health conditions such as emphysema or heart disease may lower stage I lung cancer life expectancy. Those who do not have COPD have a better prognosis than those who have the disease.
Smoking: Quitting smoking before surgery for stage I lung cancer, appears to significantly improve the survival rate. At the current time, the majority of people who develop lung cancer do not smoke...

(I note some regret that this is a ghoulish forecast given the main scenarios that cause of RBG leaving the court is due to her health deteriorating. I naturally hope my (low) estimate is not unpleasantly surprised) Rationale very similar to @Emil, but fractionally below him as: 1) I wouldn't discount much from the base-rate given the known medical conditions: the 'median 85 year old' on the life table would also likely have significant pre-existing conditions, so its not clear wrt comorbidities RBG is in on the left tail of the reference class: (note e.g. the disease specific mortality curves for bowel and pancreatic Ca are pretty flat 10+ years out, so probably aren't contributing much risk). 2) I *would* give a substantial-ish boost for affluence, social class, and education. All are recognised as (interlinked, but independently contributing statistically if not causally) protective factors for health and survival both generally and from the vast bulk of diseases individually. One example to give an impression of their size is highest versus lowest (e.g.) income quartile give an ~8 year life expectancy spread in the US (and also some evidence of compression of morbidity, such that richer people spend less lifespan in ill-health). So RBG is definitely on the right tail of the life-table reference class.  3) I agree with better medical care etc (although this would be partly included in the above consideration). So I'd start at ~8, and on balance go down to ~5.5 guesstimating these considerations (this implies HR~ 0.7 baserate, which is broadly concordant with other background data such as cancer survival when comparing highest versus approximant median bands for social class etc.) Bluntly, this is an estimate of 'dying on the bench', but there are other disjunctions to account for. Similar to Emil, I'd add ~3-4 percent for these, which would be mostly be ill-health. 85 and v. demanding job on one hand (commonsensically, no one would be shocked if someone retired in their mid eighties); political motivation to stay on and right tail fitness-for-age on the other. I find it hard to more than guestimate here as these things would not be statistically independent, but also there's lots of 'pricing in'/double counting issues. [Forgive lack of citations - if time permits I'll go back to double check my work. FWIW I used to work as a public health physician]. Aside: I would basically ignore (/price into existing considerations) that she did not attend hearings this week, as this still puts one well within (as I understand) typical recovery times for the operation she underwent. I'd start going up if this absence stretched into next month (or other worrying signals).

In view of Ginsburg’s political inclination and personal motivation, Ginsburg will not leave the Supreme Court until she passes away.  Therefore in forecasting this question, we are dealing with the probability of her death within in a year.
There are two sets of mortality statistics: one for the general population and another one for a person with a certain disease.
According to the actuarial table, the mortality rate (the probability of dying within one year) for a 85-years old (Ginsburg’s age) female is 7.5%.  (https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html).  This is our baseline number.
However since Ginsburg has had several bouts of cancer.  Survival rates for cancer patients have to be taken into consideration.  Ginsburg recovered from the first two bouts of cancer (colon cancer in 1999 and pancreatic cancer in 2009), most likely due to their early detection.  Their effects on her current health can be considered to be negligible.  
In November 2018, cancerous nodules were found in her lungs.  These nodules are considered to be in early stages of lung cancer.  I don’t know what stage the cancer is, but most likely Stages 1 or 2.  
The one-year survival rate for lung cancer patients is hard to come by.  But tables shown in the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance (https://www.seattlecca.org/diseases/lung-cancer/lung-cancer-overview/survival-rates) indicates that the one-year survival rates for Stage 1 and Stage 2 lung cancer are 87.5 and 82.5%, respectively for the Alliance patients.  The Stage 1 and 2 survival rates are lower in other treatment centers (80% and 65%, respectively).  I assume that Ginsburg will be under excellent care.  I will use the better survival rate of 85% for the two stages of lung cancer (average between 87.5 and 82.5%).
 This means there is a death rate of 15% (100-85) for an early stage cancer patient.  This is double of that (7.5%) in the general population.

As many other forecasters have pointed out, Justice Ginsburg is not going to retire while President Trump is in office. So for that reason, I'm down from 100% to 60%. In the end, if Ginsburg is incapacitated, it may not make any difference, because there is no prescribed number of Supreme Court Justices. So I wonder what the procedure would be if Justice Ginsburg were to be bedridden, extremely weak, but fully conscious and lucid when she's awake. Unable, however, to attend sessions, and hear arguments, or even watch them streamed in real time without weakening to a point where she can't meaningfully participate. In that case, would her vote on any given suit still count - or even be solicited. Moreover, could Trump get away with appointing a tenth justice who could attend to the duties required, and whose vote would count? After all, it wouldn't be illegal or unconstitutional - although it would be a radical departure from tradition and from what would widely be considered acceptable behavior. But then, we've seen a lot of departures from tradition and acceptable behavior over the years. Anyway, getting back to the question: I think forecasters are right that she will not resign for health reasons. If Trump can do an end-run around her refusal to resign, he will. And I think that Ginsburg's health may be more compromised than we are led to believe. If we hear some details about her overall condition, I may change my mind. Given her age of 85, mortality tables by the Social Security Adminsitration indicate a probability of 7.5% [1]. One the one hand, I lean toward raising this number given her known medical conditions. On the other, she is under better medical care than the average female her age. On net, I am increasing the probability by 3%. Add another ~3% (and round down) for other complications that force her to resign.  [1] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
She is a class act and a tough old bird--and as it happens a friend of the family--but sooner or later she will wear out.  Still betting on "later," but with less confidence than formerly.

She is 85. By the SS mortality table, she has a 7.5133% chance to die as base rate. Add to that her medical complications we know about, and I'm going to add 3% to that. However, that is just mortality chances. She also could be forced to leave for life situations beyond her control. So add another 3%.  Round up and I get 14%

It's partly an actuarial question. Let's round up and say she is 86. This gives her a probability of dying of 8%.[1] Then there is a question of a critical illness that prevents her from working as a judge. I think the chances of that, given her lifestyle, are lower than 2%. The lung cancer has been found early, so unlikely that it will be a factor in the coming year. [1] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html

She has dealt with such health issues before: "Ginsburg has recovered from previous medical issues. She was treated in 1999 for colon cancer and again in 2009 for pancreatic cancer but did not miss any argument sessions either time. In 2014, doctors placed a stent in her right coronary artery to improve blood flow after she reported discomfort following routine exercise. She was released from a hospital the next day."

A woman in America at her age (85 and 9 months) has a mortality rate of 0.081808 (linearly interpolated).  Given her recent health issues, I have doubled that rate.  I don't think the likelihood of her leaving for a reason other than death is high enough to consider. https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html

At her age, her recent health problems make it likelier that she will have other health problems. Unless she is particularly robust (and she doesn't strike me as such) she will probably have to retire or will die.  On the other hand, maybe it was Sean O'Casey who said, "No man is so old that he does not believe that he will live one more year." That aphorism applies to women too, and sometimes elderly people are right - they do have one more year. I'll revisit this question as the year goes on, and adjust accordingly.
